description: Docker is a set of tools that provide a runtime for creating, managing and orchestrating containers. Docker provides the ability for developers, system admins, or hobbyists to provision a container that can be configured as similarly to a virtual machine without all of the resource intensity. This series introduces the usage of the Docker client to run containers, managing the Docker daemon, using Docker Machine for provisioning runtime environments for the Docker toolset, Docker Compose for orchestrating and managing multi-container applications, as well as Docker Swarm for distributing those containers across multiple nodes in a cluster of machines. Stay tuned to get started with Docker!

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Justin show how to start managing multiple containers.  Justin demonstrates the unusual naming convention for the containers and how to change it to something meaningful.  He also demonstrates how to kill a container and what happens when you accidentally stop a container.  The guys discuss how to consider a restart when a system is rebooted or power is lost.  Justin also shows how set a restart policy for containers

NGINX, I do have an affinity for

1 million pulls, boom, it's out of order.

I'm not entirely sure what

00:06:54.460 --> 00:06:59.580
LS, pull, push, okay well, there's also,

00:08:16.010 --> 00:08:18.720

00:08:18.720 --> 00:08:21.807

00:10:01.340 --> 00:10:02.880

So I have my terminal open,
and if I type docker ps,

00:10:24.063 --> 00:10:27.024

00:10:27.024 --> 00:10:28.520

But this could easily.

00:10:40.180 --> 00:10:42.610

00:10:42.610 --> 00:10:43.811
It's an easy fix,

00:10:48.101 --> 00:10:51.540

00:10:51.540 --> 00:10:53.150
Okay that's not a big deal.

00:10:53.150 --> 00:10:56.870

00:10:56.870 --> 00:10:59.180

00:11:00.690 --> 00:11:02.620

00:11:03.930 --> 00:11:07.141
I do, and I have a worker node, all right.

00:11:07.141 --> 00:11:11.010
Now I just wanna know what's

00:11:16.610 --> 00:11:18.944

00:11:18.944 --> 00:11:25.210

00:11:25.210 --> 00:11:26.550
>> Yeah, performance information.

00:11:26.550 --> 00:11:30.984
>> Yep, so if I say docker top

00:11:30.984 --> 00:11:36.030
worker, I actually get
a snapshot of that performance.

00:11:36.030 --> 00:11:38.610
Or excuse me, of what's going on.

202
00:11:38.610 --> 00:11:41.900
Now, I don't get all
the performance information.

00:11:41.900 --> 00:11:43.210
So I misspoke there.

00:11:43.210 --> 00:11:46.990
Not performance, but
I get what is currently running.

205
00:11:46.990 --> 00:11:50.780
And notice it is the shell, right.

00:11:50.780 --> 00:11:52.970
And it has a pit ID.

00:11:52.970 --> 00:11:56.674

00:11:56.674 --> 00:12:00.360

of what processes are running,

worker.

>> [LAUGH]
>> So it gives me an ID,

00:12:43.678 --> 00:12:46.924
when it was created, the path SH,
what kind of arguments.

222
00:12:46.924 --> 00:12:50.190
So that I can actually pass these
arguments when I start them up.

223
00:12:50.190 --> 00:12:53.610
>> And it will give me
the current state it is running.

224
00:12:53.610 --> 00:12:54.610
Is it running?

00:27:20.820 --> 00:27:24.140
about the way that our
containers are running as well.

457
00:27:24.140 --> 00:27:25.520
Sometimes performance details,

458
00:27:25.520 --> 00:27:29.500
but also other information that
we made need to be able to use.

459
00:27:29.500 --> 00:27:32.920
And, of course, then managing some of
the other things that we've talked about.

460
00:27:32.920 --> 00:27:36.990
Such as being able to run separate
commands and get them attached.

461
00:27:36.990 --> 00:27:43.030
As well as being able instead to go in,
and do simple commands using the exec too.

462
00:27:43.030 --> 00:27:46.810
So, there's a lot of information that's
right here that may be very useful to you

463
00:27:46.810 --> 00:27:49.840
as you get up, and
running inside of your environment.

464
00:27:49.840 --> 00:27:53.330
That you're trying to build,
that will help you out as well.

465
00:27:53.330 --> 00:27:57.540
All right, so, Justin, any last minute
words before we close out of this episode?

466
00:27:57.540 --> 00:28:00.284
>> Well, Ronnie, I agree,
I can tell, you're just like,

467
00:28:00.284 --> 00:28:01.747
that's a lot of information.

468
00:28:01.747 --> 00:28:03.218
>> That's a lot of information.

469
00:28:03.218 --> 00:28:04.742
>> That's a lot of information.

470
00:28:04.742 --> 00:28:06.720
>> [LAUGH]
>> Do refer to the Docker docs.

471
00:28:06.720 --> 00:28:08.880
>> Right.
>> Watch this episode again,

472
00:28:08.880 --> 00:28:10.630
in our library.

473
00:28:10.630 --> 00:28:14.020
It is a lot of information, but
start up containers and play around.

474
00:28:14.020 --> 00:28:14.850
Break things.

475
00:28:14.850 --> 00:28:18.443
The wonderful thing about containers is,
if you break it, just kill it and

00:28:18.443 --> 00:28:19.254
start a new one.

477
00:28:19.254 --> 00:28:21.720
>> [LAUGH] All right,
well thank you again, Justin.

478
00:28:21.720 --> 00:28:24.330
And also, thank you for watching today.

00:28:24.330 --> 00:28:26.080

480
00:28:26.080 --> 00:28:29.300
For ITProTV,

episodes.description:
In this episode, Ronnie and Justin take a look at some of the considerations when bringing data into a docker container.  They show us that possibility that data can persist but it may not and shouldnâ€™t be considered dependable for storage.  To make data persistent between containers we may not to create volumes that map to the data somewhere else, says Justin.  Also according to guys, that containers
accessing that volume for the same information at the same time may cause corruption of the day.  The key is to be careful when using data between  containers.
episodes.title: Docker and Data

WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.270 --> 00:00:03.458

2

>> Welcome to another great

7
00:00:19.410 --> 00:00:22.150
We're specifically gonna be
taking a look at Docker and

data that we also need

Justin Dennison.

Ronnie, and how are you?

13
00:00:31.790 --> 00:00:35.870
>> I am doing great today as we

14
00:00:35.870 --> 00:00:40.380
And of course, talking about data and
working with Docker together It, and

15
00:00:40.380 --> 00:00:45.090
now, is really about the time where we've
seen a lot in previous episodes, right?

16
00:00:45.090 --> 00:00:49.360
We have taken a look at how to begin,
how to get a docker container up and

running, taking a look at, of course,

18
00:00:53.280 --> 00:00:56.057

00:00:56.057 --> 00:00:57.061
Justin, a little bit more.

20

>> Yeah.

21
00:00:57.639 --> 00:00:58.490
Yeah.

22
00:00:58.490 --> 00:01:01.420
Data is definitely a concern of ours.

23
00:01:01.420 --> 00:01:03.600
Let's set the picture a little bit.

24
00:01:03.600 --> 00:01:07.140
Let's say that I'm gonna use containers
to manage such, like a SQL database,

25
00:01:07.140 --> 00:01:11.800
Postgres, MySQL, or
even Mongo, a NoSQL database.

26
00:01:11.800 --> 00:01:15.720

27
00:01:15.720 --> 00:01:18.990

backups, what it may be, or

29
00:01:20.520 --> 00:01:24.720
To disk It's there, even if we don't see

30

31
00:01:29.730 --> 00:01:32.300

32

00:01:36.820 --> 00:01:42.050

00:01:55.352 --> 00:01:59.547

00:02:18.290 --> 00:02:22.890

43
00:02:22.890 --> 00:02:26.020

44
00:02:26.020 --> 00:02:28.560
>> All right so Justin,
the way that you're talking about it,

00:02:28.560 --> 00:02:32.100
it doesn't sound like that my data

46
00:02:32.100 --> 00:02:34.770
So how safe is it when
we start to do this and

00:02:34.770 --> 00:02:38.220
as we work with it what are some of the
considerations we have to keep in mind?

48
00:02:38.220 --> 00:02:42.020
>> So when we start working with
containers, when you're first starting

00:02:42.020 --> 00:02:45.950
to play around it's not a huge deal

50
00:02:45.950 --> 00:02:50.190
But as you start building up data bases or
you're using it for

51
00:02:50.190 --> 00:02:53.620
development I know that this is not
necessarily the standard use case.

52
00:02:53.620 --> 00:02:56.820
I've made it to wear everything's
running in a container but

00:02:56.820 --> 00:02:59.970
I'm modifying files locally and

54
00:03:01.050 --> 00:03:03.470
So how do we get there?

55
00:03:03.470 --> 00:03:07.710
How do we provide a way that
if the container goes awry,

56
00:03:07.710 --> 00:03:10.930
something breaks,
we delete it on accident or purposefully,

57
00:03:10.930 --> 00:03:13.960
that we still have that
data available to us.

58
00:03:13.960 --> 00:03:19.980
Well, there's a couple of different ways,
and we'll see how that plays out.

59
00:03:19.980 --> 00:03:22.180
So let's take a look here in the terminal.

60
00:03:22.180 --> 00:03:25.140
And I have, let's see if I
have any containers running.

61
00:03:25.140 --> 00:03:26.350
I do not.

62
00:03:26.350 --> 00:03:30.990
And let's just start by
exploring the very first way

00:03:30.990 --> 00:03:35.280
that we can make a container have

64
00:03:35.280 --> 00:03:40.106
And just to remind ourselves,

65
00:03:40.106 --> 00:03:46.383
Actually it, I-t there we go, --name.

66
00:03:46.383 --> 00:03:49.330
And I'm gonna say test.

67
00:03:49.330 --> 00:03:52.100
And that's gonna be a busy box container.

68
00:03:52.100 --> 00:03:53.410
And so, it's running.

69
00:03:53.410 --> 00:03:55.141
I'm inside the terminal now.

00:03:55.141 --> 00:03:57.330
I'm going to touch.

00:03:57.330 --> 00:04:01.670
Actually let's just ls here and

00:04:01.670 --> 00:04:06.690
Now I'm root user so

00:04:10.260 --> 00:04:16.540

00:04:20.080 --> 00:04:27.520

00:04:28.530 --> 00:04:34.380

00:05:08.642 --> 00:05:12.680

00:05:43.960 --> 00:05:47.467

00:05:51.400 --> 00:05:54.800

00:06:45.000 --> 00:06:46.070
And if I, no.

That's not a huge deal.

But, if this was the container

00:06:55.010 --> 00:07:00.450

00:07:00.450 --> 00:07:05.230

00:07:05.230 --> 00:07:08.420

00:07:08.420 --> 00:07:12.539

00:07:25.220 --> 00:07:29.820

00:07:50.470 --> 00:07:52.610
So I have my test data here.

I can give a single name,

00:08:12.510 --> 00:08:17.000

00:08:17.000 --> 00:08:18.590

00:08:19.670 --> 00:08:23.390

00:08:23.390 --> 00:08:27.670

00:08:50.980 --> 00:08:52.936

00:08:52.936 --> 00:08:53.540
This is the local.

00:08:53.540 --> 00:08:57.890
This is the container, okay?

154
00:08:57.890 --> 00:09:01.600
Local, what I call local, on my machine.

155
00:09:01.600 --> 00:09:03.360
And then to the actual container.

156
00:09:04.550 --> 00:09:09.740
And now,
I'm just going to --name test busybox.

157
00:09:09.740 --> 00:09:12.870
Now I can reuse this name because I've
deleted the previous container, and

00:09:12.870 --> 00:09:20.350
I run and notice that I have a testData

159
00:09:20.350 --> 00:09:23.960
That happened because of this

00:09:23.960 --> 00:09:26.920
All right, well,
let's actually go inside of that.

00:09:26.920 --> 00:09:28.140
I'm inside the container.

00:09:31.467 --> 00:09:35.990
There is hello.text, and if I swipe over,

00:09:37.150 --> 00:09:44.350
I actually have a test data and,

00:09:45.890 --> 00:09:49.890
I was expecting, so let's go back and
try to troubleshoot here.

166
00:09:49.890 --> 00:09:52.160
So, I'm going to get out of here.

167
00:09:52.160 --> 00:09:57.653
LS, LS test data, hm, what happened?

00:09:57.653 --> 00:10:02.510
Well, you've gotta be

169
00:10:02.510 --> 00:10:08.400
We need to make sure that this is actually

170
00:10:08.400 --> 00:10:13.230
And what I like to do is, instead I'm
gonna remove this container, by force, so

171
00:10:13.230 --> 00:10:16.230
it'll shut it down, not busybox.

172
00:10:17.650 --> 00:10:21.855
And I'm gonna docker run -it -v,
and I'm gonna say for

173
00:10:21.855 --> 00:10:26.190
the present working directory,
and then the testData.

174
00:10:26.190 --> 00:10:31.130
So I'm being more specific if you ever run
settling or anything like that you've run

175
00:10:31.130 --> 00:10:36.455
into a similar problem, and then I'm
going to pipe that to testData and

176
00:10:36.455 --> 00:10:41.220
--name and then test busybox, all right.

177
00:10:41.220 --> 00:10:44.860
So let's go back and check, okay nothing,
but I have deleted that container so

178
00:10:44.860 --> 00:10:47.590
there is nothing in there,
so if I go to test data, and

179
00:10:48.620 --> 00:10:54.080
then I touch hello.txt.

180
00:10:54.080 --> 00:11:00.950
There we go, so that's the first gotcha
when working with this volume binding.

181
00:11:02.020 --> 00:11:05.070
>> All right, so Justin, I have
a question now, when we start dong that.

182
00:11:05.070 --> 00:11:09.100
When you remove the container now, this
should still be there in the background,

183
00:11:09.100 --> 00:11:10.350
is that what we're saying?

184
00:11:10.350 --> 00:11:12.240
>> Ronnie, you're in my mind.

185
00:11:12.240 --> 00:11:13.030
That's the hope.

186
00:11:13.030 --> 00:11:15.020
I'm crossing my fingers.

187
00:11:15.020 --> 00:11:17.840
I try to be very,
very careful when it concerns that.

188
00:11:17.840 --> 00:11:20.071
No I'm not really concerned
about this hello.txt, right?

189
00:11:20.071 --> 00:11:21.680
>> [LAUGH]
>> There's nothing in it.

190
00:11:21.680 --> 00:11:23.160
There's nothing important in it.

191
00:11:23.160 --> 00:11:27.120
But I try to be very conscious
when I'm messing with data when I

00:11:27.120 --> 00:11:31.490
have data requirements
because if I mess up, whoops,

00:11:31.490 --> 00:11:36.360
all of my data's gone and Ronnie,

00:11:36.360 --> 00:11:38.950
What happens now if I

195
00:11:38.950 --> 00:11:40.440
I stop it, I delete it.

196
00:11:40.440 --> 00:11:42.740
Is hello.txt still there?

197
00:11:42.740 --> 00:11:45.680

>> [LAUGH]
>> Data store, and

00:16:10.790 --> 00:16:13.700
So I'm in a separate container now.

266
00:16:18.250 --> 00:16:23.580
Now here's the final recommendation for

267
00:16:23.580 --> 00:16:27.950
If you have multiple rights,
you could lead in, right.

268
00:16:27.950 --> 00:16:30.380
One container's writing,

269
00:16:30.380 --> 00:16:33.670
And it's not through some
system like a database that's

00:16:33.670 --> 00:16:35.470
taking care of that for you.

00:16:35.470 --> 00:16:37.150
Then you may have data corruption.

00:16:37.150 --> 00:16:40.181
Multiple reads though, you're all right.

00:16:40.181 --> 00:16:42.190
Right, reading is not destructive.

00:16:42.190 --> 00:16:46.710
But let's say that your worker node is
writing while your client is reading.

275
00:16:46.710 --> 00:16:51.470

00:16:51.470 --> 00:16:53.260
out of sync or even just data corruption.

277
00:16:53.260 --> 00:16:54.340
Things go bad.

278
00:16:54.340 --> 00:16:59.720
So definitely be careful with that, but
now that I have this data available and

00:16:59.720 --> 00:17:02.550
let's say client.txt.

00:17:02.550 --> 00:17:04.640
So I've made something else here.

281
00:17:04.640 --> 00:17:06.230
I'm gonna open up another terminal.

00:17:08.390 --> 00:17:11.378
And if I go to docker container ls --all,

00:17:11.378 --> 00:17:16.340
notice, well,
my client's there cuz I removed worker.

284
00:17:16.340 --> 00:17:23.760
But if I docker create, let's just
go back up here, well, there we go.

00:17:23.760 --> 00:17:26.120
I'm bringing my worker back online.

286
00:17:28.900 --> 00:17:31.830
Well, now you'll notice I'm

00:17:31.830 --> 00:17:34.892
Even though it's named worker, it's

00:17:34.892 --> 00:17:40.033

00:17:40.033 --> 00:17:45.840
made inside of the client container,

00:17:45.840 --> 00:17:50.760
Well, let's hop over to worker and

00:17:50.760 --> 00:17:53.150
Well there are all three there now.

00:17:53.150 --> 00:17:54.040
I'm gonna switch back.

00:17:54.040 --> 00:17:56.520
I'm now in the client container.

294
00:17:56.520 --> 00:17:58.830
I feel like I'm saying
container a great deal Ronnie.

295
00:18:00.140 --> 00:18:04.840
So if I ls,
notice that worker.txt is there.

296
00:18:04.840 --> 00:18:07.090
Now I don't have to worry,
even though I'm creating files,

297
00:18:07.090 --> 00:18:09.430
which is technically a write process.

298
00:18:09.430 --> 00:18:13.010
Because I'm not writing to the same file,
right?

299
00:18:13.010 --> 00:18:16.080
But if you have high speed web
applications that are depending on

300
00:18:16.080 --> 00:18:17.850
something like this.

301
00:18:17.850 --> 00:18:21.490
If they're writing to it and

302
00:18:21.490 --> 00:18:25.200
where they're both writing
to the exact same file name.

303
00:18:25.200 --> 00:18:28.960
That could lead to data corruption,
cuz one worker and

304
00:18:28.960 --> 00:18:31.620
one client could then
write to the same file.

305
00:18:31.620 --> 00:18:34.230
And who knows which one got there first.

306
00:18:34.230 --> 00:18:39.680
In addition to let's say the client is
a read only but the worker is a writer.

307
00:18:39.680 --> 00:18:42.290
If it writes and
a client's reading while it's writing,

308
00:18:42.290 --> 00:18:44.860
you may get data mismatch also.

309
00:18:44.860 --> 00:18:51.060
So definitely be aware that managing
data is not an easy task at hand.

310
00:18:51.060 --> 00:18:54.620
But this is incredibly powerful,
because now this data volume,

311
00:18:54.620 --> 00:18:57.840
this data store,
is always going to be there.

312
00:18:57.840 --> 00:19:01.730
Unless you go out of your way
to actually remove it, so.

313
00:19:01.730 --> 00:19:02.520
>> All right Justin.

314
00:19:02.520 --> 00:19:06.872
Since you mentioned this idea that data
can, if we have two different containers

00:19:06.872 --> 00:19:11.224
trying to access the same data, it's the
same way that we would if we had an actual

00:19:11.224 --> 00:19:14.590
physical hard drive where

00:19:14.590 --> 00:19:18.110
We'd get the same result from two

00:19:18.110 --> 00:19:22.230
But let's talk about the idea
of how safe is this?

319
00:19:22.230 --> 00:19:25.900
And we're trying to mimic such
as accessing client data.

320
00:19:25.900 --> 00:19:30.021
Behind let's say a web server, they're
trying to get access to a data base, and

00:19:30.021 --> 00:19:32.310
I'm trying to do it from a container.

00:19:32.310 --> 00:19:35.190
Is that connection somehow secure or safe?

00:19:35.190 --> 00:19:39.170
Or what other considerations do I have to
actually think about if I'm gonna try and

00:19:39.170 --> 00:19:39.840
keep that safe?

00:19:39.840 --> 00:19:44.320
>> So let me make sure that I
fully understand your question.

00:19:44.320 --> 00:19:47.530
We're talking about accessing
a connection between a database and

00:19:47.530 --> 00:19:49.350
maybe some web application

328
00:19:50.400 --> 00:19:54.640
And as we'll see,
when we actually build a web application.

00:19:54.640 --> 00:19:55.416
We're going to do that.

330
00:19:55.416 --> 00:19:56.420
>> Cool.

331
00:19:56.420 --> 00:20:00.360
>> You'll find that the network
is actually kind of bundled

00:20:00.360 --> 00:20:01.790
up in the docker ecosystem.

00:20:01.790 --> 00:20:02.940
It's a virtualized network.

334
00:20:02.940 --> 00:20:03.800
It doesn't really exist.

00:20:03.800 --> 00:20:08.460
It exists between containers and

00:20:08.460 --> 00:20:11.605
Now I say theoretically because

337
00:20:11.605 --> 00:20:12.180
>> Mm-hm.

00:20:12.180 --> 00:20:15.320
>> There are always loopholes and bugs and

00:20:15.320 --> 00:20:19.230

00:20:19.230 --> 00:20:24.160

00:20:32.800 --> 00:20:34.810
Or could we put that somewhere else, and

00:20:37.740 --> 00:20:39.320
>> So that's actually a great question.

00:20:39.320 --> 00:20:40.690
I've actually done that.

00:20:40.690 --> 00:20:42.600
I used to do some data
science type things.

00:20:42.600 --> 00:20:46.400
And we had data sets that

00:20:46.400 --> 00:20:50.181

00:20:50.181 --> 00:20:51.600

00:21:03.138 --> 00:21:06.600

00:21:06.600 --> 00:21:09.280
One thing, there's a couple of things

00:21:09.280 --> 00:21:11.450

357
00:21:11.450 --> 00:21:14.350

358
00:21:14.350 --> 00:21:17.210
You have elevated privileges all the time.

359
00:21:17.210 --> 00:21:21.730
That means if you are rm
-rf it'll do that.

360
00:21:21.730 --> 00:21:23.330
It'll get rid of everything.

361
00:21:23.330 --> 00:21:25.840
So now if you destroy
your container like that

00:21:25.840 --> 00:21:27.500

00:21:27.500 --> 00:21:31.065

00:21:31.065 --> 00:21:33.550

365
00:21:33.550 --> 00:21:37.170
Additionally we need to keep

00:21:37.170 --> 00:21:40.970

00:21:40.970 --> 00:21:45.200

00:21:50.630 --> 00:21:56.490

00:21:56.490 --> 00:21:59.351

00:22:03.780 --> 00:22:08.100

00:22:09.420 --> 00:22:13.940

Another of the considerations we have

00:23:08.280 --> 00:23:11.240

But since everything is kind of

393
00:23:17.780 --> 00:23:21.130
But as we go outside we may have to

394
00:23:21.130 --> 00:23:23.530
But there's a lot of information here,
lot of good thoughts.

395
00:23:23.530 --> 00:23:26.480
Make sure you go back and

00:23:26.480 --> 00:23:29.910

00:23:29.910 --> 00:23:35.100
So Justin any last words on this episode

00:23:36.720 --> 00:23:40.060
Well Ronnie,

You have super powers

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Justin discuss the benefits of building your own docker image.  They demonstrate how to do so and keep track of the images you create.  Justin reminds us that the images are really files that are differences from the base image we choose to create our customized image. episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Justin build upon single container applications to bring in the use of a Redis container for a simple caching layer. By building a Python based web application that uses an additional container, they use containers as application components.
